title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who was David's firstborn son according to 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:1 states that Amnon was the firstborn son of David.

questions.question: Where were David's first six sons born?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:1-3 mentions that the first six sons of David were born in Hebron.

questions.question: Who was the mother of David's son Absalom?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:2 identifies Maachah as the mother of Absalom.

questions.question: How many years did David reign in Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:4 states David reigned in Jerusalem for thirty and three years.

questions.question: Who was the mother of David's sons Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:5 states that Bathshua, daughter of Ammiel, was the mother of these sons.

questions.question: Which of these was not listed as a son of David born in Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: Amnon was born in Hebron, not Jerusalem (1 Chronicles 3:1 and 3:6-8).

questions.question: True or False: Tamar is listed as one of David's sons.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:9 mentions Tamar as David's sister, not a son.

questions.question: Who was Solomon's son according to this chapter?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:10 states that Rehoboam was Solomon's son.

questions.question: Which king is listed as the son of Josiah?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:15 lists Jehoiakim as the second son of Josiah.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And the sons of Jehoiakim: Jeconiah his son, ______ his son.'
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:16 states that Zedekiah was the son of Jehoiakim.

questions.question: Who was the son of Jeconiah mentioned in the chapter?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:17 states that Assir was a son of Jeconiah.

questions.question: True or False: Zerubbabel was a son of Pedaiah.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:19 confirms Zerubbabel as a son of Pedaiah.

questions.question: How many sons did Elioenai have according to this chapter?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:24 lists seven sons of Elioenai.

questions.question: True or False: David had sons only by his wives, no sons of concubines are mentioned.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:9 notes sons of David born to concubines separately from those by wives.

questions.question: Who was the mother of David's son Adonijah?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:2 states Adonijah was the son of Haggith.

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 3 teach us about the importance of godly family lineage in faith and obedience?
options: It shows the lineage of David and his descendants, emphasizing faithfulness through generations
It lists only the failures of David's family to discourage pride
It focuses on wealth accumulation in David's family
It highlights political power without spiritual lessons
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the lineage of David and his descendants, emphasizing faithfulness through generations
questions.explanation: The chapter traces David's descendants, showing the continuity of God's covenant and the importance of family obedience (1 Chronicles 3:1-24). This teaches us to honor and nurture godly heritage (verses 1, 10, 14, 23).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with maintaining integrity in family relationships. Based on 1 Chronicles 3, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Honoring family roles and heritage helps build a foundation of faith and integrity
Family is irrelevant to spiritual growth
Power and position are more important than family unity
Avoiding family responsibilities leads to holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Honoring family roles and heritage helps build a foundation of faith and integrity
questions.explanation: David's children and descendants are carefully listed, showing the value of family and legacy (1 Chronicles 3:1-9). This highlights the importance of family integrity as a foundation for faithfulness (verses 4, 9).

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 3 show the value of perseverance through trials in God's plan?
options: Despite challenges, the lineage of David continues, showing God's sustaining grace
Only perfect people are listed, ignoring struggles
Trials cause God's promises to fail
Lineage is unimportant to God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: Despite challenges, the lineage of David continues, showing God's sustaining grace
questions.explanation: The chapter records many generations, including those who faced exile and hardship, yet God's covenant with David's line remains (1 Chronicles 3:16-19). This teaches perseverance and trust in God's faithfulness (verses 14, 16, 19).

questions.question: What lesson about humility and gratitude can be drawn from the detailed genealogy in 1 Chronicles 3?
options: Recognizing our place in God's story helps us remain humble and thankful
Pride in ancestry is the main message
Gratitude is unnecessary when focusing on lineage
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing our place in God's story helps us remain humble and thankful
questions.explanation: The extensive list of names, including lesser-known descendants, reminds us that God's plan involves many, encouraging humility and gratitude for His work through all people (1 Chronicles 3:20-24).

questions.question: A believer wants to grow in faithfulness and obedience. How does 1 Chronicles 3 model the value of spiritual discipline through faithful family leadership?
options: The lineage from Solomon to Josiah shows consistent spiritual leadership
Only kings who failed are mentioned
Spiritual discipline is unrelated to family leaders
questions.correctAnswer: The lineage from Solomon to Josiah shows consistent spiritual leadership
questions.explanation: Verses 10-14 list Solomon's descendants, many known for their commitment to God, demonstrating the impact of faithful leadership and discipline in family and community (1 Chronicles 3:10-14).

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 3 teach us about stewardship and responsibility in family and church life?
options: The detailed genealogies show responsibilities passed through generations
Stewardship is only about money, not family
questions.correctAnswer: The detailed genealogies show responsibilities passed through generations
questions.explanation: The passage shows how leadership and responsibilities were inherited and maintained in God's plan, highlighting stewardship in family and faith communities (1 Chronicles 3:17-24).

questions.question: A believer asks about forgiveness and reconciliation in family disputes. Based on 1 Chronicles 3, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s covenant includes imperfect families, urging forgiveness and reconciliation
Families must be perfect to be blessed
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant includes imperfect families, urging forgiveness and reconciliation
questions.explanation: Although the chapter lists many descendants, it implies the complexity of family dynamics, showing God’s ongoing grace to imperfect families and the need for forgiveness (1 Chronicles 3:1-9, 16-19).

questions.question: True or False: 1 Chronicles 3 shows that David had only six sons born in Jerusalem.
questions.explanation: David had more than six sons born in Jerusalem; the text lists nine sons by Bathshua (1 Chronicles 3:5-8).

questions.question: True or False: The genealogy in 1 Chronicles 3 includes both sons of wives and concubines of David.
questions.explanation: The chapter lists sons of David by his wives but explicitly excludes sons of concubines, as stated in 1 Chronicles 3:9.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Chronicles 3, the firstborn son of David born in Hebron was ____.
questions.explanation: The text states that the firstborn son of David in Hebron was Amnon (1 Chronicles 3:1).

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 3 teach us about contentment and trust in God's timing through the lineage of David?
options: The detailed generational records show that God’s promises unfold in His time
God’s promises are immediate and always visible
Lineage shows only human effort without divine timing
Contentment is unrelated to God’s plan
questions.correctAnswer: The detailed generational records show that God’s promises unfold in His time
questions.explanation: The genealogy includes many generations, showing that God's covenant with David’s line was fulfilled over time, encouraging trust and contentment in His timing (1 Chronicles 3:10-24).

questions.question: What biblical principle about parenting and family responsibility is taught in 1 Chronicles 3?
options: Raising children in faith continues God's covenant and blessings
Parenting is a private matter unrelated to faith
Only kings need to care about family responsibility
Family is a burden with no spiritual benefit
questions.correctAnswer: Raising children in faith continues God's covenant and blessings
questions.explanation: The chapter’s emphasis on descendants highlights the importance of parenting in God's plan, passing faith and blessings through generations (1 Chronicles 3:10-15).

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 3 encourage us to be witnesses and share the Gospel through family and community?
options: By showing the spread of David’s descendants, it models influence through family and community
Only personal faith matters, not family witness
questions.correctAnswer: By showing the spread of David’s descendants, it models influence through family and community
questions.explanation: The extensive genealogy shows how faith and God’s promises were shared through families, encouraging believers to witness through their relationships (1 Chronicles 3:19-24).

questions.question: What does 1 Chronicles 3 teach about honesty and integrity in daily life through its genealogical record?
options: Accurate record-keeping reflects the importance of honesty and integrity
Genealogies are fictional and need not be truthful
Integrity is unrelated to family records
Only leaders must be honest, not families
questions.correctAnswer: Accurate record-keeping reflects the importance of honesty and integrity
questions.explanation: The chapter’s precise genealogical details reflect a commitment to truth and integrity, encouraging believers to live honestly in all areas (1 Chronicles 3:1-24).

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 3 model humility in recognizing God's sovereignty in family and leadership?
options: By listing many descendants, it shows that God, not man, ordains leadership
It highlights human achievements apart from God
Leadership is based only on personal merit
God’s role is minimal in family history
questions.correctAnswer: By listing many descendants, it shows that God, not man, ordains leadership
questions.explanation: The genealogical record emphasizes God’s hand in establishing David’s line, reminding believers to be humble and recognize His sovereignty (1 Chronicles 3:10-24).

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 3.

questions.question: Which of David's sons was born to Ahinoam the Jezreelitess in Hebron?
questions.explanation: Amnon is listed as the firstborn son of David by Ahinoam the Jezreelitess in 1 Chronicles 3:1.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Absalom was the son of Maachah, who was the daughter of ______, king of Geshur.
questions.explanation: Absalom's mother Maachah was the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur, as stated in 1 Chronicles 3:2, showing a political alliance.

questions.question: True or False: David reigned in Hebron for seven years and six months before reigning in Jerusalem.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:4 confirms David reigned in Hebron for seven years and six months before his 33 years in Jerusalem.

questions.question: Which four sons were born to David and Bathshua, daughter of Ammiel, in Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:5 names these four sons born to David and Bathshua in Jerusalem, indicating a distinct mother and location in David’s family structure.

questions.question: Which son of Solomon succeeded him and began the royal lineage recorded in this chapter?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:10 begins the listing of Solomon’s descendants with Rehoboam as his son and successor, initiating the royal Davidic line.

questions.question: Who was the fourth son of Josiah, according to the genealogy?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:15 lists Josiah’s sons in order, with Shallum as the fourth son, indicating the continuation of the Davidic lineage through multiple branches.

questions.question: Which name appears as both a son of David and a son of Jeconiah in the genealogy?
questions.explanation: Zedekiah is listed as a son of Josiah (1 Chronicles 3:15) and also as a son of Jehoiakim (1 Chronicles 3:16), showing recurring royal names and possible typological significance.

questions.question: Which son of Jeconiah is noted as the father of Salathiel?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:17 records Assir as the son of Jeconiah and father of Salathiel, linking the exile generation to the restoration lineage.

questions.question: What is the significance of Zerubbabel in the Davidic genealogy listed here?
options: He led the return from Babylonian exile
He was the first king of Israel
He was a prophet in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He led the return from Babylonian exile
questions.explanation: Zerubbabel, son of Pedaiah, is mentioned in 1 Chronicles 3:19, known historically and biblically (e.g., Ezra, Haggai) as the leader of the Jewish return and rebuilding efforts post-exile, fulfilling prophetic hopes.

questions.question: Which literary device is evident in the structured listing of David's descendants from Hebron and Jerusalem, emphasizing political and theological themes?
questions.explanation: The genealogy’s structure, contrasting sons born in Hebron and Jerusalem (1 Chronicles 3:1-8), forms a chiastic pattern highlighting David’s reign transition and theological significance of Jerusalem as God's city.

questions.question: What does the repetition of names like Elishama and Eliphelet among David's sons indicate about ancient Near Eastern naming customs?
options: Common practice of name repetition within families
Symbolic names with no family relation
questions.correctAnswer: Common practice of name repetition within families
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:6-8 shows duplicate names, reflecting a common ancient Near Eastern custom of reusing names within families, underscoring lineage continuity and honoring ancestors.

questions.question: Which theme in 1 Chronicles 3 is developed across Scripture through the genealogy from David to Zerubbabel?
questions.explanation: The genealogy from David through Solomon to Zerubbabel (1 Chronicles 3:10-24) traces the messianic line and God's faithfulness in restoration after exile, a key biblical theme.

questions.question: Which son of David listed here is known from the New Testament as an ancestor of Jesus, highlighting the intertextual connection?
questions.explanation: Nathan, a son of David mentioned in 1 Chronicles 3:5, is an ancestor of Jesus according to Luke 3, establishing an intertextual connection in messianic lineage.

questions.question: Who is referred to as Tamar in this chapter, and what does her inclusion reveal about the author's intent?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:9 mentions Tamar as sister to David’s sons, showing the chronicler's intent to present a complete family record including daughters, rare in genealogies.

questions.question: Which son of Jehoiakim is noted as the father of Jeconiah, connecting to the Babylonian exile period?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:16 links Jehoiakim to Jeconiah, who was king during the Babylonian exile, marking a critical historical and theological turning point.

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 3, which son of David was born to Ahinoam the Jezreelitess in Hebron?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:1 states that Amnon was the firstborn of David by Ahinoam the Jezreelitess. This highlights David's family line beginning in Hebron, consistent with other genealogical records like 2 Samuel 3:2 and Psalm 51 discussing David's sons.

questions.question: Who was the mother of Absalom, son of David, according to 1 Chronicles 3?
options: Maachah, daughter of Talmai king of Geshur
questions.correctAnswer: Maachah, daughter of Talmai king of Geshur
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:2 identifies Absalom’s mother as Maachah, daughter of Talmai king of Geshur. This reflects political alliances through marriage and is also mentioned in 2 Samuel 3:3, showing the integration of David's family with neighboring kingdoms.

questions.question: How many sons did David have born in Jerusalem by Bathshua, daughter of Ammiel?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:5 states that Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon—four sons—were born to David in Jerusalem by Bathshua, daughter of Ammiel. This complements the genealogical focus on Solomon, the messianic line, confirmed in Matthew 1:6-7.

questions.question: Which son of David reigned seven years and six months in Hebron before reigning in Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:4 notes David reigned seven years and six months in Hebron before 33 years in Jerusalem. This reflects God's providential plan in David establishing a united kingdom, as also recorded in 2 Samuel 5:4-5 and Acts 13:22.

questions.question: Which of these sons of Solomon was NOT listed in 1 Chronicles 3 as part of the royal lineage?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:10-14 traces Solomon’s descendants including Rehoboam, Abia, and Amon, but not David, who was Solomon’s father. This lineage emphasizes the messianic succession, aligning with Luke 3:31 and Romans 1:3.

questions.question: Who was the firstborn son of Josiah according to 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: Verse 15 identifies Johanan as the firstborn of Josiah, followed by Jehoiakim, Zedekiah, and Shallum. This succession shows the royal line leading to the exile, as also referenced in 2 Kings 23:30 and Jeremiah 22:10.

questions.question: Which son of Jehoiakim is recorded as having a son named Assir in 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:16-17 states Jeconiah, son of Jehoiakim, had a son named Assir. This genealogical detail is critical for understanding the Davidic line’s survival during exile, supported by Jeremiah 22:24-30 and Matthew 1:12.

questions.question: Zerubbabel, a key figure in post-exilic restoration, was a descendant of which son of Pedaiah?
questions.explanation: According to 1 Chronicles 3:19, Zerubbabel was a son of Pedaiah, highlighting his role in the messianic line and leadership during the return from Babylonian exile, consistent with Ezra 3:2 and Haggai 2:23.

questions.question: How many sons did Elioenai have according to 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:24 lists Elioenai’s seven sons, emphasizing the continuation of Davidic descendants who maintained identity through exile, paralleling Nehemiah 3:2 and Ezra 10:25.

questions.question: Which sister is mentioned among the sons of Zerubbabel in 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:19 mentions Shelomith as sister to Meshullam and Hananiah, sons of Zerubbabel, illustrating the inclusion of women in genealogies and the preservation of family lines, as also seen in Ruth 4:11 and Luke 3:27.

questions.question: Which son of David was born to Abigail the Carmelitess?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:1 identifies Daniel as the second son of David born to Abigail the Carmelitess. This reflects the complex family structure of David and God's providence despite human weaknesses, consistent with 2 Samuel 3:3.

questions.question: Which son of David was born to Eglah, one of his wives, as recorded in 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:3 records Ithream as born to Eglah, David’s wife. This demonstrates the complex household of David and God's sustaining of the Davidic covenant amidst multiple family lines, as in 2 Samuel 3:5.

questions.question: How many years in total did David reign according to 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:4 states David reigned seven years and six months in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem, totaling 40 years. This fulfills God's promise and is affirmed in Acts 13:22 and 2 Samuel 5:4-5.

questions.question: Which son of Josiah was the third born, as recorded in 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:15 lists Zedekiah as the third son of Josiah, who later became king and was the last king before the Babylonian exile, as also detailed in 2 Kings 24:17 and Jeremiah 37:1.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as a son of Jeconiah in 1 Chronicles 3?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 3:17-18 lists Assir, Salathiel, and Malchiram as sons of Jeconiah, but Shelomith is listed as a sister of Meshullam and Hananiah, sons of Zerubbabel, in verse 19. This distinction clarifies genealogical roles in the Davidic line.
